results.title: Rocks that originate underground
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Explains the formation of typical igneous and metamorphic rocks and the conditions under which they are formed according to indirect evidence. Also, the program investigates the requirements for the formation of intergrown crystalline mineral grains. Suitable for Upper Primary and Lower Secondary.

results.title: Rocks that form on the Earth's surface
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Explains the formation of sandstone and shale as typical sedimentary rocks, the process of compaction and cementation and the formation of limestone and coal. Uses examples and demonstrations to enhance the explanations.

results.title: Rocks and minerals: how do we identify them?
results.creator_credit: Tom Ascher and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Noticing the pattern, composition and texture of rocks we find that we can identify them, and gain clues how they are formed. Minerals are identified by tests which can lead to an understanding of processes occurring within the earth.

results.title: Rocks and minerals. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Our Earth”.
Provides clear description of how the various types of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks are formed. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Rocks and minerals
results.brief_description: Describes the three classes of rocks - igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic - and relates them to the natural conditions that produced them. Explains the varied uses of rocks and minerals in their natural state, including basalt, pumice, granite, limestone, sandstone, marble and others.

results.title: Rockets: how they work
results.brief_description: Uses animated drawings and models to show how rockets achieve motion, and compares rocket power with other types of motive power. Scenes at a rocket launching site show the count-down procedure and the take-off of a giant multistage rocket. Demonstrates the functioning of a rocket guidance system.
results.description: Uses animated drawings and models to show how rockets achieve motion, and compares rocket power with other types of motive power. Scenes at a rocket launching site show the count-down procedure and the take-off of a giant multistage rocket. Demonstrates the functioning of a rocket guidance system.

results.title: Rocket range Australia
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and Dept of the Interior
results.brief_description: The Weapons Research Establishment at Salisbury and Woomera, South Australia. Shows the Salisbury Headquarters with its workshops, scientific testing of equipment, and wind tunnel. Also life in Woomera township and weapons research on the rocket range, including the engagement of a Jindivick pilotless aircraft by a Fireflash air-to-air missile and the launching of a skylark ground-to-air rocket.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and Dept of the Interior

results.title: Rock pools: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Donald Walton, Anvil Films and Record Group and Seabourne Enterprises
results.brief_description: This film is a study of plants and animals whose structure and habits enable them to live in rock pools. The close association between plants and animals is illustrated. The ecology of rock pools is related to the rise and fall of the tide, heating and cooling, desiccation and flooding. Suitable for upper primary and lowere secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Walton, Anvil Films and Record Group and Seabourne Enterprises
